interpretation_summary: The replication executed successfully and followed the preregistered plan: the provided Stata .dta was read (via pyreadstat after runtime fixes), the April 3, 2020 snapshot was selected, cases_per_million computed, democracy rescaled as in the original .do, and OLS was estimated for cases_per_million ~ democracy + temperature + openness. The focal finding (positive and significant association between democracy and cases per million) was reproduced: the replication estimate is positive and statistically significant and similar in magnitude to the original, though slightly smaller. Differences in sample size (N=150 in replication vs reported N≈163 in original) and small numeric discrepancies likely reflect data/NA handling and environment translation; these do not overturn the main conclusion.

fidelity_assessment.method_alignment: High alignment: The executed Python script implemented the preregistered OLS model (cases_per_million ~ democracy + temperature + openness), applied the same democracy rescaling (divide-by-10 when needed), used listwise deletion for missing data, and saved the same outputs (regression text and JSON). Code changes were limited to runtime dependency fixes to read an older Stata file and ensure numpy compatibility; these did not change analysis logic.

deviations.issue_description: Runtime/environment fixes were required to read the provided .dta (installed pyreadstat at runtime and patched numpy aliases).
deviations.impact: Low: These were engineering fixes to enable reading the input file and did not change analytic transformations or modeling steps.

deviations.issue_description: Final sample size in the replication is N=150 (listwise deletion) vs the original paper's reported ~163 countries.
deviations.impact: Moderate: Differences in N can change point estimates and standard errors; this likely explains some magnitude differences (replication democracy coef smaller than original). The direction and significance remained consistent, so the impact does not change the substantive conclusion but may affect precise magnitude comparisons.

deviations.issue_description: Potential small differences in variable selection/coercion or handling of non-numeric encodings in the .dta during the Python translation.
deviations.impact: Low to Moderate: If specific rows or alternative variable name matches were handled slightly differently, coefficients could shift modestly; recommended to share processed dataset to confirm exact mapping.

results_comparison.hypothesis_tested: Primary hypothesis: Country-level democracy index is positively associated with confirmed COVID-19 cases per million (cases_per_million on 2020-04-03 regressed on democracy, controlling for average yearly temperature and economic openness).
results_comparison.original_results: Original study (post-registration/paper) reported a positive and statistically significant democracy coefficient. Extracted numbers: democracy coefficient ≈ 86.76467 (original reported), p ≈ 0.0001 (original claim). Also reported: temperature coefficient ≈ -16.55, openness ≈ 2.688 (paper/post-registration numerical summaries).
results_comparison.replication_results: Replication (Python OLS on provided .dta, N=150) produced: democracy coef = 78.95938775996943, SE ≈ 20.056, 95% CI [39.321, 118.597], p = 0.00012735 (p < 0.001). Temperature coef = -10.960870783906234, SE ≈ 5.139, p ≈ 0.0346. Openness coef = 7.81012527787758, SE ≈ 1.582, p ≈ 2.14e-06. Model: Adj. R-squared = 0.3468, No. Observations = 150. The replication outputs (text and JSON) were saved to replication_data/Hossain_Replication_results.txt and replication_data/Hossain_Replication_coefs.json.
results_comparison.overall_answer: Yes. The replication satisfies the preregistered comparison criteria for the focal claim: the democracy coefficient is positive and statistically significant (same sign and significance as original). Magnitude is similar but somewhat attenuated; sample differences and data-cleaning choices likely account for the numeric discrepancies.

replication_report: Replication successful: The focal association (more democratic countries report higher COVID-19 cases per million) is reproduced. Replicated democracy coefficient = 78.96 (SE ≈ 20.06, p < 0.001) on N=150, consistent in sign and significance with the original reported effect (≈86.76, p≈0.0001).

failure_handling.suggestions: Although execution ultimately succeeded, environment issues arose (unsupported pandas.read_stata for Stata v110, pyreadstat and numpy alias issues). Suggestion: include a requirements.txt or lockfile with tested package versions (e.g., pyreadstat==1.1.4, numpy==1.23.5) and a short README describing necessary runtime fixes so future runs do not require ad-hoc runtime installs/patches.

Address the sample-size discrepancy by (a) providing the exact processed CSV / cleaned dataset used by the replication (rows and variable encodings after coercion), (b) documenting which observations were dropped for missingness, and (c) if possible, include the original Stata processed data or a log of the .do file output (list of dropped countries). This will allow exact one-to-one numeric comparisons and clarify whether missingness or name-matching caused N differences.

No substantive method deviations were observed, but to increase confidence run specification checks: (a) include heteroscedasticity-robust standard errors (HC1/HAC) and report them, (b) run alternative COVID snapshots provided in the .dta, and (c) replicate any lagged Y residualization steps from the original .do if those were part of robustness checks in the paper.

notes: Caveats and recommendations: (1) Diagnostic output in the replication shows strong non-normality and heteroscedasticity (large Omnibus / Jarque-Bera statistics), so report robust SEs and consider transformations or outlier influence diagnostics. (2) The study is observational and cross-sectional; associations are not causal and may reflect reporting differences, testing regimes, or timing differences across countries. (3) For medium/hard-tier checks: run (a) robust/clustered SEs, (b) influence/leverage diagnostics and leave-one-out checks to see if a few countries drive the result, (c) matching the exact original N by reproducing the original data-cleaning sequence in Stata if available, and (d) sensitivity to democracy scaling (confirm the divide-by-10 mapping exactly matches original encoding). (4) Providing the processed replication dataset and an explicit mapping table between variable names/transformations would eliminate remaining minor uncertainties.
